subject: Sleep
title: Sleep Consolidation in Infants
description: A micro-lesson that makes Sleep Consolidation in Infants usable.

hook.text: At two months, a baby sleeps in 14 fragments. By 12 months, sleep consolidates into one long night plus two naps.

buildup.text: Sleep consolidation happens as the SCN matures and begins responding to light-dark cycles.

discovery.text: Melatonin production begins around three months, giving infants their first chemical signal for nighttime.

twist.text: Morning light exposure for babies accelerates circadian development and earlier sleep consolidation.

climax.text: By six months, most infants can sleep six to eight hour stretches, though individual variation is large.

punchline.text: Babies don't learn to sleep through the night. Their clocks grow into it.

quiz.question: What drives sleep consolidation in infants?
options: Maturation of the SCN and melatonin production
